title: 107_hr3676
content: The Act titled "Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Use Cessation Promotion Act of 2001" amends the Medicare program to include coverage for counseling for tobacco cessation. This includes defining counseling for cessation of tobacco use as a covered service under the Social Security Act. The term 'counseling for cessation of tobacco use' includes diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services for individuals using tobacco products, provided by a physician or other authorized healthcare professional under state law. It is limited to services in line with current clinical practice guidelines on treating tobacco use. The Public Health Service issues clinical practice guidelines for treating tobacco use and dependence. Payment for counseling services for tobacco cessation will be covered at 100 percent of the actual charge or a fee schedule determined by the Secretary. The amendments eliminate deductibles and coinsurance for counseling services for tobacco cessation in outpatient hospital settings. The amendments made by this section will apply to services provided on or after January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF COUNSELING FOR CESSATION OF TOBACCO USE UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM. Amendment to the Social Security Act includes dropping exceptions for Medicaid coverage of tobacco cessation medications and requiring coverage of counseling for pregnant women. The amendment to the Social Security Act eliminates exceptions for Medicaid coverage of tobacco cessation medications and mandates coverage of counseling for pregnant women to quit smoking. This change removes cost-sharing for tobacco cessation counseling services for pregnant women, with the effective date being services provided on or after January 1 of the first calendar year starting at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act amendment mandates coverage of tobacco cessation counseling and medications for pregnant women under the Maternal and Child Health Program, effective upon enactment of the Act.
